title: How do VCR and VHS players differ? - Quora

response.answer_text: VCR stands for Video Cassette Recorder. So it’s a device that can record onto a video cassette. This is usually VHS format, but could instead be the competing Betamax format. A VHS player would be a device capable of playing VHS cassettes. It doesn’t specify whether or not the device can record or just play back. In the vast majority of cases you’re likely to come across, they are exactly the same thing. VHS quickly won the ‘format war’ over Betamax to become the de facto standard. A VHS-format VCR became the recording device used in most homes, and could both record incoming TV channels, and play back recorded material.

VHS is a videotape cassette format, and VCR is actually the name for a type of player. But in reality, with the demise of Sony's Betamax format for home videocassettes, virtually all VCRs exclusively play VHS tapes, and virtually all videocassettes are in the VHS format.
